concept.title: Example: Using chunk to combine a group of topics
concept.shortdesc: The chunk attribute can be used on grouping elements to combine multiple source documents into one result document.

conbody.p: Assume the following map input.ditamap, where chunk is used on both topicgroup and topichead.

fig.title: Input map
fig.codeblock: <map> <title>Groups are combined</title> <topicgroup chunk="combine"> <topicref href="ingroup1.dita"/> <topicref href="ingroup2.dita"/> </topicgroup> <topichead chunk="combine"> <topicmeta> <navtitle>Heading for a branch</navtitle> </topicmeta> <topicref href="inhead1.dita"/> <topicref href="inhead2.dita"/> </topichead> </map>

conbody.p: The result of evaluating the chunk attribute on topicgroup is equivalent to a single DITA document with the content of both ingroup1.dita and ingroup2.dita.

The chunk attribute on topichead also results in a single DITA document. In many applications, a topichead is equivalent to a single title-only topic; in that case, the chunked result is equivalent to a root topic with the title "Heading for a branch", containing as child topics the content of both inhead1.dita and inhead2.dita. If topichead is ignorable in the current processing context, the chunked result would be equivalent to processing topicgroup (a single DITA document with the content of both inhead1.dita and inhead2.dita).
This reads as-if we are making an assumption that processors MAY treat topicheadelements in implementation-specific ways â€¦ Was that the authoring intent?

fig.title: Equivalent source content
fig.codeblock:
<map> <title>Groups are combined</title> <topicref href="chunkgroup-1.dita"/> <topicref href="chunkgroup-2.dita"/> </map>
chunkgroup-1.dita <dita> <!-- content of ingroup1.dita --> <!-- content of ingroup2.dita --> </dita>
chunkgroup-2.dita <dita> <topic id="head"> <title>Heading for a branch</title> <!-- content of inhead1.dita --> <!-- content of inhead2.dita --> </topic> </dita>
